metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: You can loop through the array elements with the for loop, and use the length property to specify how many times the loop should run.
content.html: You can loop through the array elements with the for loop, and use the length property to specify how many times the loop should run.

content.text: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array:
content.html: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array:

content.code:

content.code_html:
String[] cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
for (int i = 0; i < cars.length; i++) {
  System.out.println(cars[i]);
}

content.text: Loop Through an Array with For-Each
There is also a " for-each " loop, which is used exclusively to loop through elements in arrays:
content.html: There is also a "for-each" loop, which is used exclusively to loop through elements in arrays:

content.code_html:
for (type variable : arrayname) {
  ...
}

content.text: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array, using a " for-each " loop:
content.html: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array, using a "for-each" loop:

content.code:
String
[
]
cars
=

{
"Volvo"
,

"BMW"
,

"Ford"
,

"Mazda"
}
;


for

(
String
i
:
cars

System

out

(

)
;

content.code_html:
String[] cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
for (String i : cars) {
  System.out.println(i);
}

content.text: The example above can be read like this: for each String element (called i - as in i ndex) in cars , print out the value of i .
content.html: The example above can be read like this: for each String element (called i - as in index) in cars, print out the value of i.

content.text: If you compare the for loop and for-each loop, you will see that the for-each method is easier to write, it does not require a counter (using the length property), and it is more readable.
content.html: If you compare the for loop and for-each loop, you will see that the for-each method is easier to write, it does not require a counter (using the length property), and it is more readable.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the output of the following code? String[] cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"}; for (int i = 0; i < cars.length; i++) { System.out.println(cars[i]); }

What is the output of the following code?
String[] cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford"};
for (int i = 0; i < cars.length; i++) {
  System.out.println(cars[i]);
}
